event.title: the time of its incorporation in 1864

data.event: At the time of its incorporation in 1864, it had the distinction of being the smallest municipality in the Sydney metropolitan area, at a mere 44 acres.

event.title: is linked to school purposes when in 1789

data.event: The earliest recorded British history of Darlington is linked to school purposes when in 1789, Governor Arthur Phillip received instructions from England to set aside land in the new penal colony for church and school use.

event.title: 1819, fifty two acres of land was given

data.event: In 1819, fifty two acres of land was given to William Hutchinson by Governor Lachlan Macquarie.

event.title: 1835, a 28 acres land grant was made

data.event: In 1835, a 28 acres land grant was made to William Shepherd by Governor Richard Bourke.
It had been promised earlier in 1827 by Governor Ralph Darling and in his honour, Shepherd named the fruit and flower farm he established 'Shepherd's Darling Nursery'.
His nursery is still remembered today in many Darlington street names such as Ivy, Pine, Myrtle, Rose, Vine and Shepherd Streets.

event.title: 1844, the Hutchinson estate, much of Shepherd's Nursery and a portion of the adjoining 96 acre land grant to William Chippendale comprised

data.event: By 1844, the Hutchinson estate, much of Shepherd's Nursery and a portion of the adjoining 96 acre land grant to William Chippendale comprised much of present-day Darlington.
